children.desc: The goddess of good order and spring pastures. She was one of the three Horae (Seasons) and an attendant of the goddess Aphrodite

children.label: Iasion
children.desc: A springtime consort of the goddess Demeter and patron-god of her Samothracian Mysteries.

children.label: Lacedaemon
children.desc: Born when Zeus took advantage of Taygete when she was unconscious

children.label: Minos
children.desc: A lawmaking King of Crete who was appointed a judge of the dead in the underworld.

children.label: Moirae (Fates)
children.desc: The female deities who supervised fate

children.label: Atropos
children.desc: Atropos was one of the three Moirae, the Fates, who cut the thread or web of life

children.label: Klotho
children.desc: The youngest of the three Fates, who spins the thread of human life

children.label: Lakhesis
children.desc: One of the three Fates (Moirae), the :Disposer"; he measures the length of the thread of human life spun by Klotho and determines its destiny

children.label: The Muses
children.desc: The Muse of choral dance and song

children.label: Calliope
children.desc: The eldest of the Muses. She was muse of epic poetry

children.label: Clio
children.desc: The muse of history

children.label: Erato
children.desc: The Muse of lyric love poetry.

children.label: Euterpe
children.desc: The Muse of lyric poetry

children.label: Melpomene
children.desc: The Muse of tragedy

children.label: Polyhymnia
children.desc: The Muse of hymns

children.label: Terpsichore
children.desc: The Muse of choral dance and song

children.label: Thalia 1
children.desc: The Muse of comedy and pastoral poetry

children.label: Urania
children.desc: The Muse of astronomy

children.label: The Oreads
children.desc: The Greek nymphs of mountains and grottoes (from the Greek oros "mountain"). They belong to the retinue of Aphrodite

children.label: Pandia
children.desc: The goddess of brightness; a minor goddess whose name means "all bright"

children.label: Persephone
children.desc: The Queen of the underworld. She was a spring-time goddess, the only daughter of Demeter, who was abducted to the underworld by Hades. Her mother brought famineto the world until Zeus agreed to let her return for part of the year.

children.label: Zagreus
children.desc: The first-born son of Zeus who the god seated on the throne of heaven armed with thunderbolts when he was but a babe. The Titan gods stole into Olympus, distracted the child, and dismembered him with their bloody knives. Athena recovered his heart, and the god was reborn through Semele as Dionysus.

children.label: Rhadamanthys
children.desc: One of the three judges of the dead in the underworld and the Lord of the Islands of the Blessed.

children.label: Thriae
children.desc: Lesser goddesses of nature who can foresee the future or foretell the unknown by inspiration, magic, signs, or omens.  The word Thriae means "pebbles," because the future was foretold by tossing pebbles

children.label: Zagreus
children.desc: The first-born son of Zeus who the god seated on the throne of heaven armed with thunderbolts when he was but a babe. The Titan gods stole into Olympus, distracted the child, and dismembered him with their bloody knives. Athena recovered his heart, and the god was reborn through Semele as Dionysus.

children.label: Tethys
children.desc: The Titan goddess of the subterranean sources of fresh-water and the nursing of the young. She was the wife of the Titan Okeanus and bore him three-thousand fresh-water Nymphs and innumerable Rivers.

children.label: Okeanides
children.desc: Nymphs of the ocean. There were also nymphs of springs and rivers (Naiads), clouds (Nephelai), cool breezes (Aurai), meadows (Limoniads) and groves (Alseides). The eldest of them were lower ranked Titan goddesses.

children.label: Admete
children.desc: An Okeanis whose name means "the unbroken" or "unwedded". She may have been the Naias Nymphe of a wild mountain stream, or the Nephele of wild clouds and rain. Admete was perhaps a goddess of unwedded maidens, her sister Zeuxo, representing the yoke of marriage

children.label: Akaste
children.desc: An Okeanis whose name means "unstable" or "irregular". She may have been the Naias Nymphe of an erratically flowing spring or stream, or a Nephele of unpredictable rainfall. Akaste might also have been a gooddess of unpredictable behavior

children.label: Amphiro
children.desc: An Okeanis named "the surrounding flow". She may have been a Naias of a stream of Nephele of rain

children.label: Amphitrite
children.desc: The Okeanis goddess of the sea. (She was usually numbered amongst the Nereides rather than Okeanides)

children.label: Asia (Continent Asia)
children.desc: The Okeanis Nymphe of the region of Asia (or rather Anatolian peninsular). She was the wife or mother of the Titan Prometheus. Her sister was Europe

children.label: Calypso
children.desc: A goddess-nymph of the island Ogygia. She detained the hero Odysseus on her island for many years.

children.label: Maera
children.desc: A star-nymph daughter of the Titan Atlas, and wife of the Arcadian King Tegeates. She was the goddess of the scorching dog-star Sirios.

children.label: Asterope
children.desc: The "starry-eyed"; an Oceanid loved by Zeus

children.label: Beroe
children.desc: The Okeanis Nymphe of the city of Beroe (Beruit) in Lebanon

children.label: Daeira (Knowledge)
children.desc: An Okeanis Nymphe named "the knowing" or "learned". She was a goddess of the town of Eleusis, perhaps the Naias of the sacred town well

children.label: Dione
children.desc: The Okeanis Nymphe "heavenly" or "divine" was a goddess of the oracle of Dodona in Thesprotia.  Some say she was the mother of the goddess Aphrodite by Zeus.  Dione was probably the same as the Okeanis Dodone, an eponymous goddess of the shrine

children.label: Dodone
children.desc: The Okeanis Nymphe of Dodona in Thesprotia. She may have been the Naias of a local spring or well, and was perhaps the same as the Okeanis Dione

children.label: Doris
children.desc: The Oceanid goddess of the mingling of fresh water with the brine. She was the wife of the sea-god Nereus, her half-brother, and mother of the fifty Nereides.

children.label: The Nereides
children.desc: The fifty daughters who dwell in the Mediterranean Sea, these beautiful women were always friendly and helpful towards sailors fighting perilous storms. They are believed to be able to prophesize. They belong to the retinue of Poseidon

children.label: Eidyia
children.desc: The Okeanis "seeing" or "knowing" was the wife of King Aeetes of Kolkhis. She was apparently a goddess connected with the power of witchcraft

children.label: Elektra (Amber-colour)
children.desc: The Oceanid of amber-light. She was married to the wondrous sea-god Thaumas and bore him Iris, the rainbow, and the whirlwind Harpies.

children.label: Ephyra
children.desc: The eponymous Oceanid nymph of the town of Ephyra (Corinth)

children.label: Eudora
children.desc: The Okeanis "good-gifts" was perhaps a Nephele of good downfalls of rain or the Naias of a generously flowing spring

children.label: Europe (Continent Europe)
children.desc: The Okeanis Nymphe of the continent of Europe. Her sister was Asia

children.label: Eurynome 1
children.desc: The Okeanis Nymphe of "broad-pastures". She was the mother of the Kharites by Zeus. Eurynome was perhaps one of the Epimelides, Nymphai of grazing pasture

children.label: Eurynome 2
children.desc: The Okeanis Nymphe of "wide-rulership". She was the wife of the Titan Ophion

children.label: Galaxaura
children.desc: The Okeanis Nymphe "milky breeze" was probably the Aura or Nephele of the mist-clearing breeze

children.label: Hagno
children.desc: The Okeanis "holy" was one of the nurses of the infant god Zeus. She was the Naias of the Arkan spring Hagno, whose waters generated the clouds of a Nephele

children.label: Hesione
children.desc: The Okeanis "knowing" or "foresight" was a goddess of foreknowledge. She was the wife of the Titan Prometheus (forethought). Hesione was also known as Pronoia

children.label: Hippo
children.desc: The Okeanis Nymphe "horse" was the Naias of a stream or Aura of breezes - both winds and waters were often likened to horses

children.label: Hyale
children.desc: The Okeanis "crystal" or "clear like crystal" was a Nephele of rain. She was on the attendant Nymphs of Artemis

children.label: Iakhe
children.desc: The Okeanis of the ritual cry of joy "iakhe". She was a goddess of the Eleusinian Mysteries

children.label: Ianeira
children.desc: An Okeanis Nymphe, perhaps the goddess of the Ionian tribe of Greeks. Her sister Doris presided over the Dorians

children.label: Ianthe (Violet-colour)
children.desc: The Okeanis of "violet flowers" or the colour "violet". She may have been a Nephele of the violet tinged clouds of dawn, or an Anthousa (flower-nymph) of violets

children.label: Kallirhoe
children.desc: The Okeanis "fair-flowing" was either the Naias of a good flowing spring or Nephele (Cloud) of good downpours. She was the mother of the Erythian (Spanish) giant Geryon.

children.label: Kalypso
children.desc: An Okeanis whose name means "hidden", "covered"or "veiled". She may have been the Naias of a covered or hidden spring or the Aura of invisible breezes

children.label: Kamarina
children.desc: The Okeanis Nymphe of the city of Kamarina in Sicily. She was probably the Naias of the town fountain or well

children.label: Kapheira
children.desc: The Okeanis "storm-breath" was probably the Aura of strong winds. She was a nurse of the god Poseidon

children.label: Kerkeis
children.desc: One of the Okeanides

children.label: Keto
children.desc: An ancient Sea-Goddess. She personified the dangers of the sea. Most of the monsters of mythology were descended from her.

children.label: Echidna
children.desc: A deadly she-dragon with the upper body of a beautiful nymph, and the tail of a serpent in place of legs. The immortal Echidna married the hundred-headed giant Typhon and spawned a brood of terrible monsters.

children.label: The Gorgons
children.desc: A monstrous feminine creature whose appearance would turn anyone who laid eyes upon it to stone. Later there were three of them: Euryale ("far-roaming"), Sthenno ("forceful"), and Medusa ("ruler"), the only one of them who was mortal.

children.label: Euryale
children.desc: One of the two immortal Gorgons.

children.label: Medusa
children.desc: A serpent-haired Gorgon who was slain by the hero Perseus. When she was beheaded her two children by Poseidon were born from her bloody neck.

children.label: Pegasus
children.desc: A winged horse which sprung from the neck of Medusa after her decapitation. He was tamed by the hero Bellerophon who rode him into battle against the Amazons and the monster Chimera.

children.label: Chrysaor
children.desc: A giant, "Golden Falchion".

children.label: Echidna
children.desc: A deadly she-dragon with the upper body of a beautiful nymph, and the tail of a serpent in place of legs. The immortal Echidna married the hundred-headed giant Typhon and spawned a brood of terrible monsters.

children.label: Graeae
children.desc: The three "old women" or "gray ones," they were gray-haired from birth and have only one eye and one tooth, which they share among them. They are Enyo ("horror"), Deino ("dread") and Pemphredo ("alarm")

children.label: Deino
children.desc: One of the old hag Graeae.

children.label: Enyo
children.desc: The goddess of war, a battlefield companion of Ares.

children.label: Pemphredo
children.desc: One of old hag Graeae.

children.label: Thoosa
children.desc: A sea nymph loved by the god Poseidon. She was the mother of the Cyclops Polyphemus.

children.label: Polyphemos
children.desc: A man-eating Cyclops who was blinded by the hero Odysseus

children.label: Khariklo
children.desc: A Okeanis Nymphe of Mount Pelion in Thessalia. She was the wife of the wise kentauros (centaur) Kheiron

children.label: Khryseis (Gold-colour)
children.desc: The Okeanis "golden" or "golden-yellow" was probably either a Nephele of the golden-tinged clouds of sunset, or the Naias of a gold-producing mountain-spring

children.label: Klymene 1
children.desc: The Okeanis goddess of fame and infamy was the wife of the Titan Iapetos

children.label: Atlas
children.desc: The Titan-god of daring. He led the Titan-army in the war against the gods and as punishment was condemned to bear the heavens upon his shoulders.

children.label: Calypso
children.desc: A goddess-nymph of the island Ogygia. She detained the hero Odysseus on her island for many years.

children.label: The Hesperides
children.desc: The Hesperides are Aegle, Arethusa, Erytheia and Hesperia, nymphs who live in a beautiful garden.  The Hesperides are Aegle, Arethusa, Erytheia and Hesperia

children.label: The Hyades
children.desc: The sisters of the Pleiades.  In some traditions they were regarded as the nurses of either Dionysus or the infant Zeus. As a reward, they were placed in the sky as a constellation

children.label: Ambrosia
children.desc: One of the Hyades

children.label: Cleeia
children.desc: One of the Hyades

children.label: Coronis
children.desc: One of the starry Hyades.

children.label: Eudora
children.desc: One of the starry Hyades

children.label: Pedile
children.desc: One of the Hyades

children.label: Phaeo
children.desc: One of the Hyades

children.label: Phaesla
children.desc: One of the Hyades

children.label: Phyto
children.desc: One of the Hyades

children.label: Polyxo
children.desc: One of the Hyades

children.label: Theone
children.desc: One of the Hyades

children.label: Hyas
children.desc: The water-bearing son of the Titan Atlas who was killed by a lion and placed amongst the stars as the constellation Aquarius.

children.label: Maera
children.desc: A star-nymph daughter of the Titan Atlas, and wife of the Arcadian King Tegeates. She was the goddess of the scorching dog-star Sirios.

children.label: The Pleiades
children.desc: The virgin companions of Artemis. When Orion, a beautiful hunter, pursued them and their mother, they prayed to the gods for rescue. The gods answered they prayer and they were changed into doves, and later into stars. Zeus placed them in the sky where they formed a part of the constellation of Taurus

children.label: Alcyone
children.desc: One of the Pleiades. She was loved by Poseidon.

children.label: Celaeno
children.desc: One of the starry Pleiad nymphs. She was loved by the god Poseidon.

children.label: Maia
children.desc: A Pleiad star-nymph of Mount Cyllene in Arcadia. She was the mother of the god Hermes by Zeus.

children.label: Merope
children.desc: One of the Pleiad star-nymphs, the wife of the impious Corinthian King Sisyphos. Blushing in shame for her husband"s crimes, her star shone only faintly.

children.label: Sterope
children.desc: One of the starry Pleiad nymphs. She was loved by the god Ares.

children.label: Taygete
children.desc: The starry Pleiad nymph of Mount Taygetus who was loved by Zeus. She was the ancestress of the kings of Sparta.

children.label: Epimethus
children.desc: Epimetheus ("afterthought") foolishly ignored his brother Prometheus' warnings to beware of any gifts from Zeus. He accepted Pandora as his wife, thereby bringing ills and sorrows to the world. Epimetheus was made up by the Greeks as the antipode of his brother Prometheus ("forethought").

children.label: Menoetius
children.desc: The Titan god of rash anger. He was blasted into Erebus with a thunderbolt by Zeus.

children.label: Prometheus
children.desc: The Titan god of forethought and the creator of mankind. He cheated the gods on several occasions on behalf of man, including the theft of fire. As punishment Zeus chained him to the Caucasus mountains and sent an eagle to prey on his ever-regenerating liver. He was later freed by Heracles.

children.label: Klymene
children.desc: The Okeanis of fame was the mother of the Phaethon by Helios the sun. She was probably one of the Nephelai. She may be the same as Klytia

children.label: Phaeton
children.desc: The son of the sun-god Helios. He induced his father to allow him to drive the chariot of the sun across the heavens for one day. The horses ran wildly out of their course and came close to the earth, threatening to burn it. Zeus noticed the danger and with a thunderbolt he destroyed Phaeton.

children.label: Klytia
children.desc: One of the Oceanides who fell in love with the sun-god Helius. When he abandoned her she wasted away and was transformed into the sun-gazing heliotrope flower.  She may have been the same as Klymene 2

children.label: Krokale
children.desc: The Okeanis "sea-shore" was a Naias Nymphe companion of the goddess Artemis

children.label: Leuke
children.desc: An Okeanis named "the white" who was loved by Haides god of the underworld. She was transformed into the white poplar tree of the nlessed Elysian Fields

children.label: Leukippe
children.desc: The Okeanis "White-Horse" was probably the Nephele or Aura of fast moving clouds, or the Naias of a frothy white spring or mountain stream. Winds and waters were often compared to horses

children.label: Libya (Continent Africa)
children.desc: The Oceanid nymph who gave her name to the continent of Libya (Africa).  She was a sister of Europe and Asia

children.label: Melia
children.desc: The Oceanid nymph wife of the Argive river-god Inachus.  She was probably the Naias of a sweet-water spring, perhaps the same as Melia 2, who was loved by the god Apollon and was the Naias of the Theban spring Ismene

children.label: Meliboea 1
children.desc: The Okeanis "sweet-cattle" was the wife of the early Arkadian King Pelasgos. She was probably either the Naias nymphe of an Arkadian spring or the Epimelis of cattle-grazing pastures

children.label: Meliboea 2
children.desc: An Okeanis loved by the Syrian River-God Orontes

children.label: Melite
children.desc: The Okeanis "honey-sweet" was probably the Nymphe of sweet-water spring

children.label: Melobosis
children.desc: The Okeanis "food of fruit" or "sheep-feeder" was probably one of the Epimelides, Nymphai of grassy pastures or fruit trees

children.label: Menestho
children.desc: The Okeanis "swift-force" or "strong and fast" was probably the Naias of a full flowing stream, or the Aura of strongly blowing breezes

children.label: Merope
children.desc: The Okeanis "with face turned" was the mother of Phaethon by the god Helios. She was probably the same as Klymene 2

children.label: Metis (Counsel)
children.desc: The Okeanis goddess of wisdom and good-counsel. She was loved by Zeus, who swallowed her to avoid the prophecy that her son would dethrone him. She was probably one of the Nephelai

children.label: Athene
children.desc: Goddess of war and crafts who sprung fully grown and armed from the head of Zeus. She was one of the twelve great Olympian gods.

children.label: Neda
children.desc: The Okeanis goddess of the Arkadian River Neda. She was an Arkadian nurse of the infant god Zeus

children.label: Nemesis
children.parents: Nyx alone; or Okeanus and Tethys
children.desc: The Okeanis goddess of indignation and retribution for hybristic behaviour and undeserved good fortune. After being seduced by Zeus in the form of a swan, she lay the egg from which Helen was hatched. She a daughter of Nyx, but was also called a daughter of Nyx or Zeus.

children.label: Nephele 1
children.desc: A Nymphe "cloud" who was the wife of the mortal King Athamas. She rescued her two children from sacrifice by sending a flying golden-fleeced Ram to their aide (a creature reminiscent of a golden cloud)

children.label: Nephele 2
children.desc: A Nymphe formed by Zeus in the shape of Hera out of the clouds. She was raped by the criminal Ixion, and bore him the Kentauroi (Centaurs)

children.label: Nessos
children.desc: A centaur ferryman who tried to rape the wife of Heracles, Deianeira, as he was carrying her across his river. Heracles heard her screams and shot him dead with poisoned arrows. The dying centaur tricked the girl into taking a sample of his poisoned blood to use as an aphrodisiac should her husband ever prove unfaithful.

children.label: Eurytion
children.desc: A Thessalian centaur who attempted to abduct the bride of the Lapith King Peirithous on her wedding day. Most of the centaurs were slain in the battle which ensued.

children.label: Hylonome
children.desc: A female centaur. She killed herself when her husband the centaur Cyllarus was slain in the battle with the Lapiths.

children.label: Mimas
children.desc: One of the Gigantes who slain in the giant-war by Hephaestus with barage of red-hot metal.

children.label: Rhoikos
children.desc: One of the Gigantes

children.label: Nephele 3
children.desc: The Okeanis Nymphe "cloud" was one of the virgin Nephelai attendants of the goddess Artemis

children.label: Nymphai Artemis
children.desc: The fifty youngest Okeanides were handmaidens of the goddess Artemis

children.label: The 5 Nysiades
children.desc: Five Okeanides of Mt Nysa in Phoinikia who nursed the god Dionysos and became the first of his Bakkhantes

children.label: Okyrhoe
children.desc: The Okeanis "swift-flowing" was either a Naias of fast flowing spring, or Nephele of falling rain

children.label: Ourania
children.desc: The "heavenly-one" was probably an Okeanis Nephele (of the clouds)

children.label: Paregoron
children.desc: The Okeanis goddess of consolation and soothing words. She was an attendant of the goddess Aphrodite

children.label: Pasithoe
children.desc: An Okeanis whose name means "all-swift". She was probably either the Naias of a fast-flowing spring or an Aura of the swift breeze

children.label: Periboia
children.desc: The Okeanis "surrounded by cattle" was the wife of the Titan Lelantos. She was probably the Naias of a pasture-feeding stream

children.label: Peitho (Persuasion)
children.desc: The Oceanid goddess of persuasion and seductive words. She was the nurse and close companionof the goddess Aphrodite.

children.label: Perseis
children.desc: An Okeanis-eponym of Persia and mother by Helios of the eastern despots Aeetes and Perses, and the witches Pasiphae and Kirke. Her name also means "destroyer" who probably was a goddess of the destructive power of witches

children.label: Aegea
children.desc: Sister to Circe and Pasiphae, and daughter of the sun. When the Titans attacked the gods of Olympus, Gaia placed Aega in a cave to hide her shining loveliness

children.label: Aetes
children.desc: King of Colchis;  Aetes is the father of the sorceress Medea.

children.label: Circe
children.desc: An immortal witch who dwelt on the island of Aeaea. She turned travellers into beasts with her potions.

children.label: Pasiphae
children.desc: A goddess-witch of the island of Crete, the wife of King Minos. She was filled with an unnatural desire for the Cretan Bull and after mating it conceived the bull-headed Minotaur.

children.label: Perses
children.desc: The Titan god of destruction and laying waste.

children.label: Hecate
children.desc: The Titan goddess of witchcraft, ghosts and necromancy. She assisted Demeter in her search for Persephone, and became her minister in Hades.

children.label: Phaethusa
children.desc: A nymph daughter of the sun-god Helios, and the shepherdess of his flocks on the island of Thrinacie.

children.label: Petraie (Stoney-grey-colour)
children.desc: The Okeanis "of the rocks" or "stone-grey" was probably the Naias of a rocky spring, or Nephele of dark grey clouds

children.label: Phaino
children.desc: The Okeanis "appearing" or "shining" was perhaps the Nephele of the appearance of cloud, or the Naias of a bright spring

children.label: Phiale
children.desc: The Okeanis "water-pitcher" was one of the companions of the goddess Artemis. She was either a spring Naias or rain-pouring Nephele

children.label: Philyre
children.desc: An Oceanid nymph, daughter of Oceanus and Tethys, loved by the Titan Cronus. When Rhea discovered their rendezvous, he transformed himself into a stallion. From their union, the centaur Chiron was born. When Philyra saw her son, she asked Zeus to transform her into another form, and became a linden tree. Goddess of beauty, perfume, healing, and writing, and the inventor of paper.

children.label: Chiron
children.desc: An immortal Centaur son of Cronus. He was famed for his wisdom and dwelt in a cave on Mt Pelion where he fostered and trained many of the great heroes.

children.label: Ocyrhoe
children.desc: A Naiad nymph of the island of Samos who was pursued by the god Apollon. When she attempted to flee the island by ship he turned the vessel to stone and transformed the pilot into a porpoise.

children.label: Pleione (Many)
children.desc: The Oceanid nymph wife of the Titan Atlas. She and her seven daughters, the Pleiades, were pursued by the lusty giant Orion for seven years before the gods placed them amongst the stars.

children.label: The Pleiades
children.desc: The virgin companions of Artemis. When Orion, a beautiful hunter, pursued them and their mother, they prayed to the gods for rescue. The gods answered they prayer and they were changed into doves, and later into stars. Zeus placed them in the sky where they formed a part of the constellation of Taurus

children.label: Alcyone
children.desc: One of the Pleiades. She was loved by Poseidon.

children.label: Celaeno
children.desc: One of the starry Pleiad nymphs. She was loved by the god Poseidon.

children.label: Maia
children.desc: A Pleiad star-nymph of Mount Cyllene in Arcadia. She was the mother of the god Hermes by Zeus.

children.label: Merope
children.desc: One of the Pleiad star-nymphs, the wife of the impious Corinthian King Sisyphos. Blushing in shame for her husband"s crimes, her star shone only faintly.

children.label: Sterope
children.desc: One of the starry Pleiad nymphs. She was loved by the god Ares.

children.label: Taygete
children.desc: The starry Pleiad nymph of Mount Taygetus who was loved by Zeus. She was the ancestress of the kings of Sparta.

children.label: Plexaure
children.desc: The Okeanis of the "weaving breeze" was likely one of the Aurai

children.label: Plouto (Wealth)
children.desc: The Okeanis goddess of wealth was probably a Nephele of fertile rains, prospering the agricultural crop

children.label: Polydora
children.desc: The Okeanis "many gifts" might have been the Nephele of generous downfalls

children.label: Pronoia
children.desc: The Nymphe named "foresight" was the wife of the Titan Prometheus. She was a goddess of the shrine of Delphoi, and probably the same as the Okeanis Hesione

children.label: Prymno
children.desc: The Okeanis "root" or "undermost" was probably the Naias Nymphe of groundwater, or the waters of a deep well

children.label: Psekas
children.desc: The Okeanis "rain-shower" was a Nephele companion of the goddess Artemis

children.label: Rhanis
children.desc: An Okeanis named "rain-drop". She was one of the Nephelai attendants of the goddess Artemis

children.label: Rhodeia (Rose-colour)
children.desc: The Okeanis named "of the roses" or "rose-coloured" was either an Anthousa flower-nymphe, Naias of a rose-draped spring, or Nephele of the rose-tinged clouds of dawn

children.label: The 7 Heliadae
children.desc: The Heliadae were the seven sons of Helios, the sun god and the nymph Rhodus, daughter of Poseidon. The names of the seven sons were Ochimus, Cercaphus, Macareus ( or Macar), Actis, Tenages, Triopas, and Candalus.

children.label: Rhodope
children.desc: The Okeanis "rosey-eyed" was probably either an Anthousa flower-nymphe of Nephele of the rose-coloured clouds of dawn. A Naiad nymph daughter of the Thracian river-god Strymon. When she and her husband Haemus impersonated Zeus and Hera, the angry gods transformed them into mountains.

children.label: Styx (hate)
children.desc: The goddess of the underworld river Styx, eldest of the Oceanids. She brought her children to side with Zeus in the Titan-War, and as reward he made her waters the inviolate oath of the gods.

children.label: Bia
children.desc: The goddess of force. She sided with Zeus in the Titan-War and became one of his chief attendants.

children.label: Nike
children.desc: The goddess of victory who sided with Zeus in the Titan-War and became his constant companion.

children.label: Cratos
children.desc: The personification of strength and power.

children.label: Zelus
children.desc: The personification of rivalry. He and his three siblings were daemon attendants of the god Zeus.

children.label: Telesto (Success)
children.desc: The Okeanis goddess of success and accomplishment. She was probably one of the Nephelai, an ethereal goddess

children.label: Theiosa
children.desc: An Okeanis nurse of the infant Zeus in Arkadia

children.label: Thoe
children.desc: The Okeanis "swift" might have been a Naias, Nephele or Aura Nymphe

children.label: Tykhe (Fortune)
children.desc: The Okeanis goddess of fortune or chance was probably one of the heavenly Nephelai

children.label: Xanthe (Yellow-colour)
children.desc: The Okeanis "yellow" or "yellow-brown" was probably either a Naias of a muddy flowing stream, or the Nephele of the yellowed clouds of dawn and dusk

children.label: Zeuxos
children.desc: An Okeanis named "the yoked" was probably a goddess of marriage, brides being yoked in marriage. She may have been a Naias or Nephele Nymphe, in the sense of a yoked or tamed horse

children.label: Potamoi
children.desc: The River god sons of Oceanus. Each river had its own god. They were manlike from the chest upwards, but below were bodied with the serpentine tail of a fish.

children.label: Aigaios (River of Skheria)
children.desc: A river of Scheria (island of the Phaeacians) and its god.

children.label: Akheloios (River of Aitolia)
children.desc: A river of Aetolia and its god. He wrestled Heracles for the hand of Deianeira but lost the contest and with it his horn.

children.label: Alpheios (River of Arkadia and Elis)
children.desc: A river of Elis and its god. He fell in love with the nymph Arethusa and pursued her all the way to the island Ortygia. Artemis then transformed her into a spring to escape him but Alpheius guided his stream under the sea to Sicily so he could forever mingle his waters with hers.

children.label: Amnisos (River of Krete)
children.desc: A river of Crete and its god.

children.label: Anigros (River of Elis)
children.desc: A river of Elis and its god.

children.label: Askanios (River of Mysia)
children.desc: A River of Mysia and its god.

children.label: Asopos (River of Argos and Boiotia) (w/ Metope)
children.desc: A river of Boeotia and Argos and its god. He had twenty beautiful daughters, most of whom were carried off by the gods. Asopus pursued Zeus when he abducted Aegina but was driven back by the god"s thunderbolts.

children.label: Aigina
children.desc: A naiad daughter of the river Asopus. She was loved by Zeus who carried her off to the island of Aegina. When her father pursued them Zeus struck him with a thunderbolt.

children.label: Salamis
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the river Asopus who was abducted to the island of the same name by the god Poseidon.

children.label: Nemea
children.desc: The Naiad nymph of the town of Nemea. She was a daughter of either Zeus and Selene or the river Asopus.

children.label: Harpina
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the river Asopus who was abducted to Elis by Ares.

children.label: Thebe
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the river Asopus abducted to the town of Thebes by Zeus..

children.label: Plataia
children.desc: The Naiad nymph of the Boeotian town of Plataea loved by Zeus. The god pretended to be taking her for his bride when Hera abandoned their marriage.

children.label: Thespia
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the river Asopus. She was carried off to Boeotia by the god Apollo.

children.label: Tanagra
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the river Asopus. The gods Ares and Hermes competed a boxing match to win her love.

children.label: Euboia
children.desc: A Naiad daughter of the river Asopus carried off by Poseidon to the island of Euboea.

children.label: Korkyra
children.desc: A Naiad daughter of the river Asopus. She was loved by Poseidon who carried her off to the island of Corcyra.

children.label: Sinope
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the river Asopus who was abducted tot he town of Sinope on the Black Sea by Apollo. She made him swear to respect her virginity.

children.label: Peirene
children.desc: The weeping Naiad nymph of the fountain of the town of Corinth. She was loved by Poseidon.

children.label: Kleone
children.desc: The Naiad nymph of the town of Cleonae in Argos.

children.label: Ismene
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the River Asopus, and the wife of King Argus.

children.label: Asopis
children.desc: A Naiad daughter of the river Asopus.

children.label: Khalkis
children.desc: A Naiad daughter of Asopus. The town of Chalcis in Euboea was named after her.

children.label: Asterion (River of Argos)
children.desc: A river of Mycenae and its god.

children.label: Akraia
children.desc: A naiad daughter of the river Asterion. With her sisters Euboea and Prosymna she nursed Hera as a child.

children.label: Prosymna
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the river Asterion. She and her sisters Euboea and Acraea were nurses of the goddess Hera.

children.label: Euboia
children.desc: A Naiad daughter of the river Asopus carried off by Poseidon to the island of Euboea.

children.label: Axios (River of Paionia)
children.desc: A river of Paeonia and its god.

children.label: Caanthus
children.desc: A River-god son of the Titan Oceanus who was slain by Apollo in their rivalry for the love of the Nymph Melia.

children.label: Erasinos (River of Argos)
children.desc: A river of Argos and its god.

children.label: Ankhinoe
children.desc: An Egyptian Naiad.

children.label: Byze
children.desc: A Naiad daughter of the river Erasinus. With her sisters she was an attendant of Britomartis.

children.label: Melite
children.desc: A Naiad nymph of the island of the Phaeacians. She was seduced by Heracles.

children.label: Moira
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the river Erasinus who, with her sisters, was an attendant of the goddess Britomartis.

children.label: Eridanos (River of N. Europe)
children.desc: A river of northern Europe or Italy and its god.

children.label: Euenos (River of Aitolia)
children.desc: A river of Aetolia and its god.

children.label: Eurotas (River of Lakonia)
children.desc: A river in Laconia and its god. He was the first King of Sparta.

children.label: Grenikos (River of Troad)
children.desc: A river of Troy and its god.

children.label: Alexirhoe
children.desc: A naiad daughter of the river Grenicus of Troy.

children.label: Pegasis
children.desc: A Trojan Naiad nymph.

children.label: Gyge (Lake of Lydia)
children.desc: A lake of Lydia and its god.

children.label: Hebros (River of Thrake)
children.desc: A river of Thrace and its god.

children.label: Hermos (River of Lydia)
children.desc: A river of Lydia and its god.

children.label: Hydaspes (River of India)
children.desc: An Indian River-God who fought and was defeated by Dionysus in the Indian Wars.

children.label: Imbrasos (River of Samos)
children.desc: A river of the island of Samos and its god.

children.label: Ilissos (River of Attika)
children.desc: A river of Athens and its god.

children.label: Pharmakeia
children.desc: The Naiad nymph of a poisonous spring near the town of Athens.

children.label: Inakhos (River of Argos)
children.desc: A river of Argos and its god. When Poseidon and Hera were contesting for dominion of Argos, he ruled in favour of Hera. Poseidon in anger caused his stream to run dry.

children.label: Mykene
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the river Inachus after whom the city of Mycenae was named.

children.label: Kallithyia
children.desc: A Naiad daughter of the river Inachus who founded the ancient cult of Hera in Argos.

children.label: Philodike
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the river Inachus, the wife of a Messenian king.

children.label: Io
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the river Inachus. She was loved by Zeus who transformed her into a cow to hide her from the jealous gaze of Hera. The goddess was not fooled and sent a maddening gladfly to torment her. It drove her to wander all the way to Egypt, where she gave birth to Epaphus, ancestor of the Pharaohs.

children.label: Amymone
children.desc: The Naiad of an Argive spring who was loved by the god Poseidon.

children.label: Messeis
children.desc: The Naiad nymph of an Argive spring, a daughter of the River Inachus.

children.label: Hypereia
children.desc: The Naiad nymph daughter of the River-god Inachus.

children.label: Ismenos (River of Boiotia)
children.desc: A River of Boeotia and its god.

children.label: Dirke
children.desc: The Naiad nymph of the sacred fountain of Dionysus on Mount Cithaeron.

children.label: Strophia
children.desc: The Naiad nymph of a spring on Mount Cithaeron.

children.label: Ismenis
children.desc: A Naiad daughter of the River Ismenos loved by the god Faunus.

children.label: Istros (River of Skythia)
children.desc: A god of the river Danube in Scythia.

children.label: Kaikos (River of Teuthrania)
children.desc: A river of Teuthrania and its god.

children.label: Kaystros (River of Lydia)
children.desc: river of Lydia and its god.

children.label: Kebren (River of Troad)
children.desc: A river of Troy and its god.

children.label: Oinone
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the river Cebren of Troy. She was the first wife of Prince Paris who refused to heal him when he later returned to her seeking a cure for his mortal arrow-wound. She refused, and when he died she hung herself in remorse.

children.label: Hesperia
children.desc: A naiad daughter of the river Cebren.

children.label: Lilaia
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the river Cephisus.

children.label: Daulis
children.desc: A Naiad nymph after whom the Boeotian town of Daulis was named.

children.label: Thyia
children.desc: A Naiad nymph of Mount Parnassus loved by the god Apollo. She was the first to celebrate the orgies of Dionysus at Delphi.

children.label: Diogenia
children.desc: A naiad daughter of the river Cephisus. She was the wife of an Athenian nobleman.

children.label: Khremetes (River of Libya)
children.desc: A river of Libya and its god.

children.label: Ankhiroe
children.desc: An Arcadian Naiad nymph.

children.label: Kokytos (River of Hades)
children.desc: The underworld river of wailing and its god.

children.label: Mintha
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the underworld river-god Cocytus. She was transformed into a mint plant by Persephone when her affair with the god Hades was discovered.

children.label: Kytheros (River of Elis)
children.desc: A river of Elis and its god.

children.label: Ladon (River of Arkadia)
children.desc: A hundred-headed dragon which guarded the golden apples of the Hesperides. It was slain by Heracles.

children.label: Metope
children.desc: The Naiad nymph wife of the Argive river-god Asopus.

children.label: Thelpousa
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the Arcadian river Ladon.

children.label: Themis
children.desc: The Titan goddess of divine law, natural order and the oracles of the earth. She was the mother of the goddess Fates and Seasons by Zeus.

children.label: Thriae
children.desc: Lesser goddesses of nature who can foresee the future or foretell the unknown by inspiration, magic, signs, or omens.  The word Thriae means "pebbles," because the future was foretold by tossing pebbles

children.label: The Horai
children.desc: The Horae (the Hours) are the goddesses of the seasons (the Greek had only three seasons; spring, summer and winter). They are called Thallo, Auxo and Carpo, names which denote budding, growth and ripening.  The twelve Horai, who were daughters of Helios, were not always clearly distinguishable from the three Horai of the seasons, who were also described as overseeing the paths of the sun.

children.label: Dike
children.desc: The goddess of justice. She was one of the three Horae (Seasons)

children.label: Eirene
children.desc: One of the three Horae, the goddess of peace and spring

children.label: Eunomia
children.desc: The goddess of good order and spring pastures. She was one of the three Horae (Seasons) and an attendant of the goddess Aphrodite

children.label: Moirae (Fates)
children.desc: The female deities who supervised fate

children.label: Atropos
children.desc: Atropos was one of the three Moirae, the Fates, who cut the thread or web of life

children.label: Klotho
children.desc: The youngest of the three Fates, who spins the thread of human life

children.label: Lakhesis
children.desc: One of the three Fates (Moirae), the :Disposer"; he measures the length of the thread of human life spun by Klotho and determines its destiny

children.label: Syrinx
children.desc: A Naiad nymph chased by the god Pan. She fled his embrace and was transformed by her sisters into river reeds. The god crafted his famous pan-pipes from her plant.

children.label: Lamos (River of Phoinikia)
children.desc: A river of Cilicia or Mount Helicon in Boeotia and its god. He and his sons and daughters were nurses of the god Dionysus.

children.label: Lethe (River of Hades)
children.desc: The female personification of forgetfulness.

children.label: Maiandros (River of Karia)
children.desc: A river of Caria and its god.

children.label: Neilos (River of Aigyptos) (w/ Kallirrhoe)
children.desc: The river of Egypt and its god.

children.label: Memphis
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the River Nile. She was the wife of the very first Egyptian king Epaphus, who named his capital after her.

children.label: Ankhinoe
children.desc: An Egyptian Naiad.

children.label: Kaliadne
children.desc: An Egyptian Naiad.

children.label: Polyxo
children.desc: An Egyptian naiad.

children.label: Anippe
children.desc: A Naiad daughter of the River Nile loved by Poseidon.

children.label: Khione
children.desc: The goddess or nymph of snow. She was a daughter of the winter-god Boreas loved by the god Poseidon.

children.label: Peneios (River of Thessalia) (w/ Kreusa)
children.desc: A river of Thessaly and its god.

children.label: Daphne
children.desc: A naiad daughter of the river Peneius. She was loved by the god Apollo who pursued her through the woods. As he was about to capture her she prayed to Gaea and was transformed into a laurel tree.

children.label: Stilbe
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the Thessalian river Peneius loved by the god Apollo.

children.label: Menippe
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the river Peneius.

children.label: Kyrene
children.desc: A Naiad nymph huntress of Thessaly who was loved by the god Apollo. She bore him the rustic god Aristaeus.

children.label: Phasis (River of Kholkis)
children.desc: A river of Colchis and its god.

children.label: Pitane
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the Spartan river Eurotas. She was loved by Poseidon.

children.label: Pleistos (River of Phokis)
children.desc: A river of Phocis and its god.

children.label: Korykia
children.desc: One of the Corycian nymphs of Delphi loved by the god Apollo.

children.label: Pyriphlegethon (River of Hades)
children.desc: The underworld river of fire and its god.

children.label: Saggarios (River of Phrygia) (w/ Kybele )
children.desc: A river of Phrygia and its god.

children.label: Simoeis (River of Troad)
children.desc: A river of Troy and its god.

children.label: Astyokhe
children.desc: A Naiad daughter of the Trojan river Simoeis. She married a Trojan king.

children.label: Hieromneme
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the river Simoeis, and wife of the Dardanian prince Assaracus.

children.label: Skamandros (River of Troad)
children.desc: A river of Troy and its god. When he attempted to drown the hero Achilles in the Trojan War, Hephaestus scorched his streams with fire.

children.label: Kallirhoe
children.desc: An Oceanid wife of the giant Chrysaor. She begged her son Geryon not to battle Heracles.

children.label: Strymo
children.desc: A Naiad nymph daughter of the Trojan river Scamander.

children.label: Glaukia
children.desc: A Naiad daughter of the river Scamander. She was loved by a companion of Heracles.

children.label: Sparte
children.desc: The Naiad nymph wife of Lacedaemon, the first King of Sparta.

children.label: Sperkheios (River of Malis)
children.desc: A river of Malis and its god.

children.label: Diopatre
children.desc: A Malian Naiad nymph loved by Poseidon. The god turned her sisters into poplars while he seduced her.

children.label: Strymon (River of Thrake) (w/ Neaera )
children.desc: A river of Thrace and its god.

children.label: Euadne
children.desc: A naiad daughter of the river Strymon married to Argus king of Argos.

children.label: Rhodope
children.desc: The Okeanis "rosey-eyed" was probably either an Anthousa flower-nymphe of Nephele of the rose-coloured clouds of dawn. A Naiad nymph daughter of the Thracian river-god Strymon. When she and her husband Haemus impersonated Zeus and Hera, the angry gods transformed them into mountains.

children.label: Tereine
children.desc: A Thracian Naiad nymph loved by the god Ares.

children.label: Symaithos (River of Sikelia)
children.desc: A Sicilian river and its god.

children.label: Aganippe
children.desc: A naiad daughter of the river Termessus. She was the nymph of a sacred spring of the Muses whose waters had the power of inspiration.

children.label: Tiasa
children.desc: The Naiad nymph of a Spartan stream.

children.label: Theia
children.desc: The Titan goddess of sight and clear blue skies. With her brother and husband, Hyperion, she was the mother of Helios (the Sun), Eos (the Moon), and Selene (the Dawn).

children.label: Eos
children.desc: The Titan goddess of the dawn. She was cursed by Aphrodite with an insatiable appetite for men, loving one after another - Cephalus, Tithonus, Phaethon, Orion.

children.label: Astraea
children.desc: The younger Titan-goddess of justice. Astraea left the earth at the end of the Golden Age and entered the heavens as the constellation Virgo.

children.label: Boreas
children.desc: The purple-haired, winged god of the North-Wind. He was also the god of winter who carried snow on his chill breath.

children.label: Eosphorus
children.desc: The god of the morning star who heralded the arrival of dawn.

children.label: Eurus
children.desc: The god of the East Wind (or more specifically the South-East Wind).

children.label: Hesperus
children.desc: The god of the evening star (Venus).

children.label: Notus
children.desc: The god of the South Wind.

children.label: Zephyrus
children.desc: The god of the gentle West-Wind and the season of spring.

children.label: Selene
children.desc: The goddess of the moon who rode through the sky at night in a chariot drawn by winged horses, or seated side-saddle on an ass. She fell in love with the young shepherd Endymion who was granted mmortality in a state of eternal sleep.

children.label: Themis
children.desc: The Titan goddess of divine law, natural order and the oracles of the earth. She was the mother of the goddess Fates and Seasons by Zeus.

children.label: Thriae
children.desc: Lesser goddesses of nature who can foresee the future or foretell the unknown by inspiration, magic, signs, or omens.  The word Thriae means "pebbles," because the future was foretold by tossing pebbles

children.label: The Horai
children.desc: The Horae (the Hours) are the goddesses of the seasons (the Greek had only three seasons; spring, summer and winter). They are called Thallo, Auxo and Carpo, names which denote budding, growth and ripening.  The twelve Horai, who were daughters of Helios, were not always clearly distinguishable from the three Horai of the seasons, who were also described as overseeing the paths of the sun.

children.label: Dike
children.desc: The goddess of justice. She was one of the three Horae (Seasons)

children.label: Eirene
children.desc: One of the three Horae, the goddess of peace and spring

children.label: Eunomia
children.desc: The goddess of good order and spring pastures. She was one of the three Horae (Seasons) and an attendant of the goddess Aphrodite

children.label: Moirae (Fates)
children.desc: The female deities who supervised fate

children.label: Atropos
children.desc: Atropos was one of the three Moirae, the Fates, who cut the thread or web of life

children.label: Klotho
children.desc: The youngest of the three Fates, who spins the thread of human life

children.label: Lakhesis
children.desc: One of the three Fates (Moirae), the :Disposer"; he measures the length of the thread of human life spun by Klotho and determines its destiny

children.label: Typhon
children.desc: A monstrous storm-daemon with a hundred beastly heads, serpent legs and giant wings. He attempted to dethrone Zeus, and wrestled the god of his lightning bolts, tore out his sinews and locked him in a cave. The god was restored by his sons, and struck Typhone with his thunderbolts, imprisoning him in Tartarus or beneath the volcano Etna.

children.label: Khronos (Time)
children.desc: The Protogenos (primeval god of time) whose serpentine form was entwined with that of Ananke, the goddess of necessity, at the beginning of time. Together they split open the world egg.

children.label: Nyx (Night)
children.desc: The Protogenos (Primeval goddess) of night. She was the mother of Light and Day by the god Erebus (Darkness). Alone she spawned a host of spirits.

children.label: Aether ("Upper Air")
children.desc: Protogenos of light, the bright upper air (the shining blue of the sky).  He was the Brother of Hemera (Day), with whom he gave birth to Thalassa, the sea

children.label: Thalassa
children.desc: The Protogenos (primeval goddess) of the sea, the female counterpart to Pontos

children.label: Charon ("fierce, bright-eyed")
children.desc: A daemon of the underworld who ferried the dead across the river Acheron

children.label: Daimones (spirits)
children.desc: Moros, male daimon of Destiny; Thanatos, male daimon of peaceful death; and the Keres, female daimones of violent death

children.label: Apate
children.desc: The female daimon (Spirit) of deceit, guile, fraud and deception.  Her male counterpart was Dolos the daimon of trickery and wiles

children.label: Eris
children.desc: The goddess of strife who haunted the battlefield. She indirectly caused the Trojan War by throwing the golden apple to the fairest amongst the goddesses.  One of the two Erites with Enyo, goddes of war.

children.label: Algaea
children.desc: Personification of pains and sorrows

children.label: Amphillogea
children.desc: Goddess of disputes

children.label: Androctasia
children.desc: "The Killer of Men"

children.label: Ate
children.desc: The personification of error, delusion, ruin and blind folly. She led both the gods and men to rash and inconsiderate actions. Zeus threw her physically out of heaven.

children.label: Dysnomia
children.desc: The female personification of lawlessness.

children.label: Horcos
children.desc: Deity who most troubles men upon earth when anyone wilfully swears a false oath

children.label: Lethe
children.desc: The female personification of forgetfulness.

children.label: Limos
children.desc: The emaciated female personification of hunger.

children.label: Malchai
children.desc: "Battles"

children.label: Neicea
children.desc: The female personifications of grievance and quarrel.

children.label: Phonos
children.desc: Deity of murders and slaughtering

children.label: Ponos
children.desc: The personification of hard labour.

children.label: Pseudia
children.desc: Goddess of lies and falsehoods

children.label: Usmine
children.desc: Goddess of fighting and combat

children.label: Geras
children.desc: The male personifaction of old age.

children.label: Hypnos
children.desc: The winged god of sleep.

children.label: Lyssa
children.desc: The female daimon (Spirit) of rage (particularly martial rage), fury, raging madness, frenzy, and, in animals, the madness of rabies.

children.label: Momus
children.desc: The male daimon (Spirit) of mockery, blame, ridicule, scorn, complaint and stinging criticism.  He was thrown out of heaven by Zeus for his scarping criticisms of the gods

children.label: Moros
children.desc: The male daimon (or Spirit) of doom. He was the force which drove a man to his fated death

children.label: Nemesis
children.parents: Nyx alone; or Okeanus and Tethys
children.desc: The Okeanis goddess of indignation and retribution for hybristic behaviour and undeserved good fortune. After being seduced by Zeus in the form of a swan, she lay the egg from which Helen was hatched. She a daughter of Nyx, but was also called a daughter of Nyx or Zeus.

children.label: Oizys
children.desc: The female personification of pain

children.label: Oneiroi
children.desc: Spirits of dreams, whose leader, Morpheus, visited kings in their sleep in the guise of men bearing messages from the gods.  Morpheus was god of prophetic dreams, who appeared in the sleep of kings as a human shaped phantasm. His two brothers, Icelus and Phantasus, assumed the forms respectively of animals and inanimate objects

children.label: Philotes
children.desc: The female personification of affection, friendship and perhaps also sex.  Her opposite number were the Neikea (Feuds)

children.label: Thanatos
children.desc: The Daimon (Spirit) of non-violent death

children.label: Hemera (Day)
children.desc: The Protogenos (Primeval goddess) of day. She was the sister of Aether (Light), with whom she gave birth to Thalassa, the sea

children.label: Thalassa
children.desc: The Protogenos (primeval goddess) of the sea, the female counterpart to Pontos

children.label: Hesperides (Evening)
children.desc: The three goddesses of the evening and golden sunsets (Aigle, Erytheia, Hesperethoosa)

children.label: The Keres
children.desc: Female spirits of death and doom who also act as avenging spirits

children.label: Tartarus (Hell)
children.desc: The Protogenos (primeval god) of the storm-wracked pit of Tartarus, which lay beneath the flat earth. His realm was the prison of the Titan gods. Tartarus fathered the monstrous storm-daemon Typhoeus.

children.label: Typhon
children.desc: A monstrous storm-daemon with a hundred beastly heads, serpent legs and giant wings. He attempted to dethrone Zeus, and wrestled the god of his lightning bolts, tore out his sinews and locked him in a cave. The god was restored by his sons, and struck Typhone with his thunderbolts, imprisoning him in Tartarus or beneath the volcano Etna.
